Agata, Salita Sperone 3198166MesinaItaly+98 (811) 8242044haskey1@yahoo.com+98 (811) 8411501mrezaeivala@gmail.commrezaeivala@hut.ac.ir28420159201512916651675642015161220145420152842015© Iranian Chemical Society 20152015Abstract

Four macrocyclic Schiff base ligands (L1, L2, L3, and L4) have been prepared. In the presence of Copper(II), original macrocycles were converted to the three new binuclear polymeric complexes [Cu2L21′](NO3)2, [Cu2L22′](NO3), and [Cu2L23′](NO3)2. But in the presence of Nickel(II), macrocyclic rings remained unchanged and Schiff base complexes of [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 and [NiL4](NO3)2 were synthesized. All ligands and their related complexes were characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy, in the case of ligands 1H, 13C NMR and EI-Mass and for [Cu2L2′](NO3)2 and [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 complexes X-ray crystal structure determination have been performed. Crystal structure showed 1D zigzag polymer for [Cu2L21′](NO3)2 and macrocyclic structure for [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 complexes. The ligands and related polymeric complexes were screened for their antibacterial activities against six bacterial strains and the complexes showed antibacterial effects.

Introduction

The interest in exploring new metal ion complexes with macrocycles containing nitrogen and oxygen donor atoms has been increasing, because they became very attractive to be used in supramolecular and coordination chemistry [1]. Particularly important are systems that are related to bioactive molecules such as metalloporphyrins, corrins, and antibiotics [2]. X-ray structures of key complexes (largely containing metal ions of intermediate hardness) were determined and collectively indicated a varied structural chemistry across the complexes investigated. While, in a number of structures, the metal ion occupies the macrocyclic cavity and binds to all five ring donors [3, 4], in other cases non-coordination of either donors were observed [5–8] with the metal residing either endo or exo with respect to the macrocyclic cavity; or in some cases the presence of metal ion could change structure of ligands [9]. There is a continued interest in synthesizing macrocyclic complexes [10, 11] because of their applications in fundamental and applied sciences [12, 13] and importance in the area of coordination chemistry and for their biological properties, i.e., toxicity against bacterial growth [14], anticancerous [15], and other biochemical properties [16].

Schiff base ligands are among the most versatile and useful ligands and their metal complexes have been widely used as catalysts for many organic reactions such as ring-opening polymerization and oxidation [17–20]. Some research groups have studied the structural and magnetic characterization of mono- and binuclear complexes of transition metal ions containing N2O2 tetradentate Schiff base ligands [21–33] specially copper(II) and nickle(II) complexes [34–40].

Recently, we reported the biological activities of some new synthesized Schiff base complexes [41–45]. As an extension of this idea, we report in this work the synthesis, characterization, and antibacterial activities of four potentially tetradentate macrocyclic Schiff base ligands, L1, L2, L3, and L4 from [1+1] cyclocondensation of 1,2-bis(2-formylphenoxymethyl)benzene and 1,2-diaminoethane or 1,2-diaminopropane or 1,3-diaminopropane or 2,2 dimethyl 1,3-diaminopropane. After the addition of the copper(II) salts to the ligand solutions, surprisingly three polymeric binuclear open-chain complexes have been isolated while by the addition of Ni(II) metal salts to the same related solution of macrocyclic ligands ring opening does not occur and related macrocyclic complexes have been obtained (Scheme 1). The crystal structures of [Cu2L21′](NO3)2 and [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 are also reported.

ExperimentalChemical and starting materials

α, α-O-Dibromoxylene, 1,2-diaminoethane, 1,3-diaminopropane, 2,2-dimethyl-1,3- propanediamine and 1,2-diaminopropane, and metal salts were obtained from the Merck Company and were used without further purification.

Caution α, α-o-Dibromoxylene is a very caustic matter. While we have not experienced any problems with the compound described. It should be treated and handled with caution.

General synthesis of the ligands (<bold>2</bold>)

1,2-Bis(2-formylphenoxymethyl)benzene was prepared according to the literature method [46]. 1,2-Diaminoethane, 1,3-diaminopropane, 2,2-dimethyl 1,2-diaminopropane, and 1,2-diaminopropane (0.3 mmol) in dry methanol (10 mL) were added dropwise to a boiling solution of 1,2-bis(2-formylphenoxymethyl)benzene (0.104 g, 0.3 mmol) in the same solvent (15 mL). After being refluxed for 12 h, the solution was concentrated in rotary evaporated to ca. 5 mL and the precipitate was filtered and washed by diethyl ether and acetonitrile and dried in vacuum.

General method of synthesis of Cu(II) complexes

Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.108 g, 0.3 mmol) was dissolved in dry methanol (10 mL) and slowly added to a stirred boiling solution (20 mml) of L1, L2, or L3 (0.3 mmol) in the same solvent with refluxing continuing for 6 h. The solution was reduced to ca. 5 ml and the precipitate was filtered and washed by diethyl ether and acetonitrile and dried in vacuum. Crystals suitable of [Cu2L21′](NO3)2 for X-ray diffraction studies were obtained by slow diffusion of Et2O vapor into the MeOH/MeCN solution of the above solid.

General method of Synthesis of Ni(II) complexes

Ni(II) metal salts (0.25 mmol) were dissolved in dry methanol (10 mL) and slowly added to a stirred boiling solution (20 mmol) of L1 or L4 (0.3 mmol) in the same solvent with refluxing continued for 6 h. The solution was reduced to ca. 5 ml and the precipitate was filtered and washed by diethyl ether and dried in vacuum. Crystals suitable of [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 for X-ray diffraction studies were obtained by slow diffusion of Et2O vapor into the MeOH/MeCN solution of the above solid.

Physical measurements

IR spectra were measured on a Perkin Elmer FT-IRGX spectrophotometer. Mass spectra were recorded using VARIAN 3400 GC-Mass spectrometer. NMR spectra were measured on Bruker DPX 400 spectrometers. Elemental analyses were performed in a Carlo-Erba EA microanalyser.

X-ray crystal structure determination

Single-crystal data for [Cu2L21′](NO3)2 and [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 were collected at room temperature with a Bruker APEX II CCD area-detector diffractometer using Mo Ka radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data collection, cell refinement, data reduction, and absorption correction were performed using multiscan methods with Bruker software [47–49]. The structures were solved by direct methods using SIR2004 [50]. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by the full-matrix least-squares method on F2 using SHELXL [51]. The hydrogen atoms of NH2 groups were found in difference Fourier map and refined isotropically. The other hydrogen (H) atoms were placed at the calculated positions and constrained to ride on their parent atoms. Details concerning collection and analysis are reported in Table 1.

Materials and methodsAntibacterial studyTest organisms for antibacterial assay

The standard strains of the following microorganisms were used as test organisms: Salmonella typhi (Lio), Escherichia coli (PTCC 10009), Serratia marcescens (PTCC 1330), Klebsiella oxytoca (Lio), Bacillus cereus (ATCC 7064), and Staphylococcus saprophyticus (ATCC 6633). Some microorganisms were obtained from Persian Type Culture Collection, Tehran, Iran and others locally isolated (Lio). The organisms were sub-cultured in nutrient broth and nutrient agar (Oxiod Ltd.) for using in experiments, while diagnostic sensitivity test agar (DST) (Oxoid Ltd.) was used in antibiotic sensitivity testing.

Sensitivity testing

For bioassays, suspension of approximately 1.5 × 108 cells per mL in sterile normal saline was prepared as described by Forbes et al. [52]. The sensitivity testing was determined using agar-gel diffusion method [53, 54]. In each disks 20 µL of each chemical, containing 10 µg in DMSO, were loaded. The minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of chemicals was also determined using a two-fold dilutions method (NCCLS [55]). The isolated bacterial strains were first grown in nutrient broth for 18 h before use. The inoculum suspensions were standardized and then tested against the effect of the chemicals at an amount of 20 µL for each disk in DST medium. The plates were later incubated at 37 ± 0.5 °C for 24 h after which they were observed for zones of inhibition. The effects were compared with the standard antibiotic chloramphenicol at a concentration of 1 mg/mL [56]. The minimum inhibitory concentrations (MIC) of the chemicals were also determined by tube-dilution techniques in Mueller–Hinton broth (Merck) according to NCCLS [55]. The experiments were repeated at least three times for each organism and the data were presented as the mean ± SE of 3–5 samples.

Results and discussion

The Schiff base macrocyclic ligands, L1, L2, L3, and L4 were prepared from [1+1] condensation of 1,2-diaminoethane, 1,3-diaminopropane, 2,2-dimethyl 1,3-diamino propane, 1,2-diaminopropane, and 1,2-bis(2-formylphenoxymethyl)benzene. These ligands were characterized by elemental analyses, EI-Mass, IR spectroscopy, 1H NMR (in all case), and 13C NMR (in case of L1, L2, and L4). These solid compounds are air stable and elemental analyses are consistent with the formulations given in Sect. 2.

In addition of the Cu(II) and Ni(II) metal salts to the metanolic solution of these different ligands, macrocyclic complexes (in the case of Ni(II) metal salt) and polymeric open-chain complexes (in the case of Cu(II) metal salt) have been obtained. In polymeric open-chain complexes, copper(II) nitrate plays a vital role in converting ligand structures to the polymeric open-chain complexes instead of macrocyclic ones. These complexes were characterized by elemental analyses and IR spectroscopy in all cases and X-ray crystallography in the case of [Cu2L21′](NO3)2 and [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 confirm the above suggestion. In previous work, in similar structures, we have reported that the closure of macrocyclic ring in the presence of Co(II) and Zn(II) metal ions did not occur but when Ni(II) or Cu(II) metal ions were used then only macrocyclic complexes were the final product [9]. In this work, because of the preferential structural requirement caused by exerting extra force due to steric hindrance imposed by the electronic nature of the copper(II) ion, polymeric open-chain complexes were obtained instead of macrocyclic ones.

In all three similar IR spectra of prepared Cu(II) complexes, a sharp peak exhibit at the range 1623–1642 cm−1 have been referred to C=N vibration and nitrate groups have shown a peak at 1384 cm−1 and absorptions attributable to NH2 groups were found at approximately 3100–3300 cm−1. Elemental analyses of polymeric complexes are consistent with the formulations given in Sect. 2.

Crystal structuresCrystal structure of [Cu<sub>2</sub>L<sub arrange="stack">2</sub><sup arrange="stack">1′</sup>](NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>

The crystal structure of [Cu2L21′](NO3)2 has been determined by X-ray diffraction. The molecular structures with the atomic numbering scheme and selected bond lengths and bond angles are given in Fig. 2.

[Cu2L21](NO3)2 crystallizes in the monoclinic P2(1)/n space group. This is a binuclear complex. The first copper ion is coordinated to two oxygen atoms and two nitrogen atoms of ligand and one oxygen atom of nitrate group, and has distorted square pyramidal geometry. The second copper ion is coordinated also to another oxygen atom of nitrate ion as well and has distorted octahedral geometry. There is a moderate intramolecular hydrogen bond between the oxygen atom of nitrate group and hydrogen of NH2 group (N4-H4A…O6 (2.152(3) Å) (Fig. 3).

Atoms O1 and O2 of this compound play as a bridge leading to a binuclear complex. O2-Cu2-N3 angle have minimum deviation (0.68°) and O2-Cu2-O1 have maximum deviation (14.62o) from normal range (90o) of a regular square. The four Cu–N bond lengths lay in the range 1.951–1.977 Å, affording an average Cu–N bond distance of 1.963 Å. The distances between the Cu atoms and oxygen atoms are between 1.921 and 2.012 Å (minimum for Cu1-O1 and maximum for Cu2-O1). The Cu–N and Cu–O bond length are all within a normal distance for a Cu–O and Cu–N bond length [57–66]. The Cu–Cu distance in the dimeric entity is 2.9538(4) Å. A further distinguishing feature in [Cu2L21′](NO3)2 is that the two coordinated nitrate groups are on the same side of the Cu2O2 ring in the dimer.

In this structure, we have two different nitrate groups. One of them is as terminal group and another acts as bridge group. The two oxygen atoms of bridged nitrate group are linked to two different copper atoms that create 1D zigzag chain coordination polymer (Fig. 4). The two Cu–O bond lengths of bridged nitrate group are quite diverse [Cu(1)-O(4) = 2.450(2), Cu(2)-O(3) = 2.567 (3)].

The structure can be best described as 1D zigzag chain coordination polymer which are further packed along the bisector angle of ac plane sustained by hydrogen bonding involving nitrate ions and hydrogen atoms of NH2 group via N–H…O interactions [(x-1/2, −y + 1/2, +z+1/2) with dimensions 0.892(5), 2.990(5), 2.290(5) Å, 135.22(4)º].

X-ray crystal structures of [NiL<sup>1</sup>(CH<sub>3</sub>CN)<sub>2</sub>(CH<sub>3</sub>OH)<sub>2</sub>](ClO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>

Suitable crystals of [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 was obtained from a acetonitrile/methanol solution by slow diffusion of diethyl ether. The ORTEP view of the complex is shown in Fig. 5. Crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters are given in Table 1 and selected bond distances and angles are given in Fig. 1.

[NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 crystallizes in the monoclinic P-1 space group. The Ni(II) ion binds to two nitrogen of acetonitrile N(3) and N(4) and two oxygen atoms of methanol, O(3) and O(4) and also the azomethine nitrogen atoms N(1) and N(2) in a distorted octahedral geometry. The Ni–N bond lengths are nearly identical to each other (Ni(1)-N(1) 2.10(4) Å, Ni(1)-N(2) 2.09(3) Å) with a N(1)-Ni(1)–N(2) bond angle of 85.43(14)°. The bond length of Ni(1)-O(3) and Ni(1)-O(4) are 2.08(4) Å and 2.17(5) Å, respectively. The ether oxygen atoms in 16-membered macrocycle, O(1) and O(2), are not coordinated, lying at 4.86(3) Å and 5.08(3) Å, distances, respectively, from the Ni(II) ion [67]. The perchlorate anions do not interact with the metal ion.

Antibacterial activities

Antibacterial activities of the chemicals were studied against four gram-positive and four gram-negative bacterial strains (Table 2). The all prepared chemicals inhibited the growth of bacterial strains producing a zone diameter of inhibition from 8.0 to 14.0 mm, depending on the susceptibility of the tested bacteria. The most effective ones are [Cu2L21](NO3)2 against Bacillus cereus, [Cu2L22](NO3)2 against Klebsiella oxytoca, and [Cu2L23](NO3)2 against Klebsiella oxytoca. Although the most studied chemicals exhibited antibacterial properties but their effects are less than a standard Chloramphenicol antibiotic.

Since the comparison of the size of inhibition zones merely is not trustworthy, the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of the chemicals was also determined according to the method of NCCLS [55]. Results indicated that the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of the chemicals against the tested organisms varied between 16 against Bacillus cereus and Klebsiella oxytoca until 22 against Staphylococcus saprophyticus µg mL−1. The standard chloramphenicol had MIC values varying between 1 and 8 µg mL−1. The results indicated that standard antibiotic chloramphenicol had stranger activity than the chemicals against some bacterial strains. Antibacterial effect of the other chemicals is also notable.

Conclusion

In summary, we report the successful synthesis of four macrocyclic Schiff base ligands by the [1+1] condensation of 1,2-diaminoethane or 1,3-diaminopropane, 2,2 dimethyl 1,3-diaminopropane or 1, 2-diaminopropane and 1,2-bis(2-formylphenoxymethyl)benzene. These ligands were characterized by various spectroscopic methods. After addition of the Ni(II) metal salt to the metanolic solution of L1 and L4, two macrocyclic complexes have been obtained but after addition of the copper(II) nitrate to the metanolic solution of ligands, three polymeric open-chain complexes have been obtained. The crystal structures of [Cu2L21′](NO3)2 can be best described as 1D zigzag chain coordination polymer and crystal structure of [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 show macrocyclic one. Results of this research showed that most prepared chemicals have relatively antibacterial effects against the studied bacterial strains, but the most effective ones are [Cu2L21′](NO3)2 against Bacillus cereus, [Cu2L22′](NO3)2 against Klebsiella oxytoca, and [Cu2L23′](NO3)2 against Klebsiella oxytoca.

S. Agata, Salita Sperone 3198166MesinaItalya+98 (811) 8242044haskey1@yahoo.comc+98 (811) 8411501mrezaeivala@gmail.commrezaeivala@hut.ac.ir28420159201512916651675642015161220145420152842015© Iranian Chemical Society 20152015AbstractFour macrocyclic Schiff base ligands (L1, L2, L3, and L4) have been prepared. In the presence of Copper(II), original macrocycles were converted to the three new binuclear polymeric complexes [Cu2L21'](NO3)2, [Cu2L22'](NO3), and [Cu2L23'](NO3)2. But in the presence of Nickel(II), macrocyclic rings remained unchanged and Schiff base complexes of [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 and [NiL4](NO3)2 were synthesized. All ligands and their related complexes  were characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy, in the case of ligands 1H, 13C NMR and EI-Mass and for [Cu2L2'](NO3)2 and [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 complexes X-ray crystal structure determination have been performed. Crystal structure showed 1D zigzag polymer for [Cu2L21'](NO3)2 and macrocyclic structure for [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 complexes. The ligands and related polymeric complexes were screened for their antibacterial activities against six bacterial strains and the complexes showed antibacterial effects.KeywordsMacrocyclic ligandSchiff base complexX-ray crystal structure1D zigzag polymerMacrocyclic complexAntibacterial effectspublisher-imprint-nameSpringervolume-issue-count12issue-article-count21issue-toc-levels0issue-pricelist-year2015issue-copyright-holderIranian Chemical Societyissue-copyright-year2015article-contains-esmYesarticle-numbering-styleUnnumberedarticle-registration-date-year2015article-registration-date-month4article-registration-date-day6article-toc-levels0toc-levels0volume-typeRegularjournal-productArchiveJournalnumbering-styleUnnumberedarticle-grants-typeRegularmetadata-grantOpenAccessabstract-grantOpenAccessbodypdf-grantRestrictedbodyhtml-grantRestrictedbibliography-grantRestrictedesm-grantOpenAccessonline-firstfalsepdf-file-referenceBodyRef/PDF/13738_2015_Article_641.pdftarget-typeOnlinePDFissue-online-date-year2015issue-online-date-month6issue-online-date-day30issue-print-date-year2015issue-print-date-month6issue-print-date-day29issue-typeRegulararticle-typeOriginalPaperjournal-subject-primaryChemistryjournal-subject-secondaryAnalytical Chemistryjournal-subject-secondaryInorganic Chemistryjournal-subject-secondaryPhysical Chemistryjournal-subject-secondaryBiochemistry, generaljournal-subject-secondaryOrganic Chemistryjournal-subject-collectionChemistry and Materials Scienceopen-accessfalseElectronic supplementary materialThe online version of this article (doi:10.1007/s13738-015-0641-9) contains supplementary material, which is available to authorized users.IntroductionThe interest in exploring new metal ion complexes with macrocycles containing nitrogen and oxygen donor atoms has been increasing, because they became very attractive to be used in supramolecular and coordination chemistry [1]. Particularly important are systems that are related to bioactive molecules such as metalloporphyrins, corrins, and antibiotics [2]. X-ray structures of key complexes (largely containing metal ions of intermediate hardness) were determined and collectively indicated a varied structural chemistry across the complexes investigated. While, in a number of structures, the metal ion occupies the macrocyclic cavity and binds to all five ring donors [3, 4], in other cases non-coordination of either donors were observed [5-8] with the metal residing either endo or exo with respect to the macrocyclic cavity; or in some cases the presence of metal ion could change structure of ligands [9]. There is a continued interest in synthesizing macrocyclic complexes [10, 11] because of their applications in fundamental and applied sciences [12, 13] and importance in the area of coordination chemistry and for their biological properties, i.e., toxicity against bacterial growth [14], anticancerous [15], and other biochemical properties [16].Schiff base ligands are among the most versatile and useful ligands and their metal complexes have been widely used as catalysts for many organic reactions such as ring-opening polymerization and oxidation [17-20]. Some research groups have studied the structural and magnetic characterization of mono- and binuclear complexes of transition metal ions containing N2O2 tetradentate Schiff base ligands [21-33] specially copper(II) and nickle(II) complexes [34-40].Recently, we reported the biological activities of some new synthesized Schiff base complexes [41-45]. As an extension of this idea, we report in this work the synthesis, characterization, and antibacterial activities of four potentially tetradentate macrocyclic Schiff base ligands, L1, L2, L3, and L4 from [1+1] cyclocondensation of 1,2-bis(2-formylphenoxymethyl)benzene and 1,2-diaminoethane or 1,2-diaminopropane or 1,3-diaminopropane or 2,2 dimethyl 1,3-diaminopropane. After the addition of the copper(II) salts to the ligand solutions, surprisingly three polymeric binuclear open-chain complexes have been isolated while by the addition of Ni(II) metal salts to the same related solution of macrocyclic ligands ring opening does not occur and related macrocyclic complexes have been obtained (Scheme 1). The crystal structures of [Cu2L21'](NO3)2 and [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 are also reported.ExperimentalChemical and starting materialsα, α-O-Dibromoxylene, 1,2-diaminoethane, 1,3-diaminopropane, 2,2-dimethyl-1,3- propanediamine and 1,2-diaminopropane, and metal salts were obtained from the Merck Company and were used without further purification.Caution α, α-o-Dibromoxylene is a very caustic matter. While we have not experienced any problems with the compound described. IR (KBr, cm-1): 1618 υ (C=N), 1384, υ(NO3-).Physical measurementsIR spectra were measured on a Perkin Elmer FT-IRGX spectrophotometer. Mass spectra were recorded using VARIAN 3400 GC-Mass spectrometer. NMR spectra were measured on Bruker DPX 400 spectrometers. Elemental analyses were performed in a Carlo-Erba EA microanalyser.X-ray crystal structure determinationSingle-crystal data for [Cu2L21'](NO3)2 and [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 were collected at room temperature with a Bruker APEX II CCD area-detector diffractometer using Mo Ka radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data collection, cell refinement, data reduction, and absorption correction were performed using multiscan methods with Bruker software [47-49]. The structures were solved by direct methods using SIR2004 [50]. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by the full-matrix least-squares method on F2 using SHELXL [51]. The hydrogen atoms of NH2 groups were found in difference Fourier map and refined isotropically. The other hydrogen (H) atoms were placed at the calculated positions and constrained to ride on their parent atoms. Details concerning collection and analysis are reported in Table 1.Materials and methodsAntibacterial studyTest organisms for antibacterial assayThe standard strains of the following microorganisms were used as test organisms: Salmonella typhi (Lio), Escherichia coli (PTCC 10009), Serratia marcescens (PTCC 1330), Klebsiella oxytoca (Lio), Bacillus cereus (ATCC 7064), and Staphylococcus saprophyticus (ATCC 6633). Some microorganisms were obtained from Persian Type Culture Collection, Tehran, Iran and others locally isolated (Lio). The organisms were sub-cultured in nutrient broth and nutrient agar (Oxiod Ltd.) for using in experiments, while diagnostic sensitivity test agar (DST) (Oxoid Ltd.) was used in antibiotic sensitivity testing.Sensitivity testingFor bioassays, suspension of approximately 1.5 × 108 cells per mL in sterile normal saline was prepared as described by Forbes et al. [52]. The sensitivity testing was determined using agar-gel diffusion method [53, 54]. In each disks 20 µL of each chemical, containing 10 µg in DMSO, were loaded. The minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of chemicals was also determined using a two-fold dilutions method (NCCLS [55]). The isolated bacterial strains were first grown in nutrient broth for 18 h before use. The inoculum suspensions were standardized and then tested against the effect of the chemicals at an amount of 20 µL for each disk in DST medium. The plates were later incubated at 37 ± 0.5 °C for 24 h after which they were observed for zones of inhibition. The effects were compared with the standard antibiotic chloramphenicol at a concentration of 1 mg/mL [56]. The minimum inhibitory concentrations (MIC) of the chemicals were also determined by tube-dilution techniques in Mueller-Hinton broth (Merck) according to NCCLS [55]. The experiments were repeated at least three times for each organism and the data were presented as the mean ± SE of 3-5 samples.Results and discussionThe Schiff base macrocyclic ligands, L1, L2, L3, and L4 were prepared from [1+1] condensation of 1,2-diaminoethane, 1,3-diaminopropane, 2,2-dimethyl 1,3-diamino propane, 1,2-diaminopropane, and 1,2-bis(2-formylphenoxymethyl)benzene. These ligands were characterized by elemental analyses, EI-Mass, IR spectroscopy, 1H NMR (in all case), and 13C NMR (in case of L1, L2, and L4). These solid compounds are air stable and elemental analyses are consistent with the formulations given in Sect. 2.In addition of the Cu(II) and Ni(II) metal salts to the metanolic solution of these different ligands, macrocyclic complexes (in the case of Ni(II) metal salt) and polymeric open-chain complexes (in the case of Cu(II) metal salt) have been obtained. In polymeric open-chain complexes, copper(II) nitrate plays a vital role in converting ligand structures to the polymeric open-chain complexes instead of macrocyclic ones. These complexes were characterized by elemental analyses and IR spectroscopy in all cases and X-ray crystallography in the case of [Cu2L21'](NO3)2 and [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 confirm the above suggestion. In previous work, in similar structures, we have reported that the closure of macrocyclic ring in the presence of Co(II) and Zn(II) metal ions did not occur but when Ni(II) or Cu(II) metal ions were used then only macrocyclic complexes were the final product [9]. In this work, because of the preferential structural requirement caused by exerting extra force due to steric hindrance imposed by the electronic nature of the copper(II) ion, polymeric open-chain complexes were obtained instead of macrocyclic ones.In all three similar IR spectra of prepared Cu(II) complexes, a sharp peak exhibit at the range 1623-1642 cm-1 have been referred to C=N vibration and nitrate groups have shown a peak at 1384 cm-1 and absorptions attributable to NH2 groups were found at approximately 3100-3300 cm-1. Elemental analyses of polymeric complexes are consistent with the formulations given in Sect. 2.Crystal structuresCrystal structure of [Cu2L21'](NO3)2The crystal structure of [Cu2L21'](NO3)2 has been determined by X-ray diffraction. The molecular structures with the atomic numbering scheme and selected bond lengths and bond angles are given in Fig. 2.[Cu2L21](NO3)2 crystallizes in the monoclinic P2(1)/n space group. This is a binuclear complex. The first copper ion is coordinated to two oxygen atoms and two nitrogen atoms  of ligand and one oxygen atom of nitrate group, and has distorted square pyramidal geometry. The second copper ion is coordinated also to another oxygen atom of nitrate ion as well and has distorted octahedral geometry. There is a moderate intramolecular hydrogen bond between the oxygen atom of nitrate group and hydrogen of NH2 group (N4-H4A…O6 (2.152(3) Å) (Fig. 3).Atoms O1 and O2 of this compound play as a bridge leading to a binuclear complex. O2-Cu2-N3 angle have minimum deviation (0.68°) and O2-Cu2-O1 have maximum deviation (14.62o) from normal range (90o) of a regular square. The four Cu-N bond lengths lay in the range 1.951-1.977 Å, affording an average Cu-N bond distance of 1.963 Å. The distances between the Cu atoms and oxygen atoms are between 1.921 and 2.012 Å (minimum for Cu1-O1 and maximum for Cu2-O1). The Cu-N and Cu-O bond length are all within a normal distance for a Cu-O and Cu-N bond length [57-66]. The Cu-Cu distance in the dimeric entity is 2.9538(4) Å. A further distinguishing feature in [Cu2L21'](NO3)2 is that the two coordinated nitrate groups are on the same side of the Cu2O2 ring in the dimer.In this structure, we have two different nitrate groups. One of them is as terminal group and another acts as bridge group. The two oxygen atoms of bridged nitrate group are linked to two different copper atoms that create 1D zigzag chain coordination polymer (Fig. 4). The two Cu-O bond lengths of bridged nitrate group are quite diverse [Cu(1)-O(4) = 2.450(2), Cu(2)-O(3) = 2.567 (3)].The structure can be best described as 1D zigzag chain coordination polymer which are further packed along the bisector angle of ac plane sustained by hydrogen bonding involving nitrate ions and hydrogen atoms of NH2 group via N-H…O interactions [(x-1/2, -y + 1/2, +z+1/2) with dimensions 0.892(5), 2.990(5), 2.290(5) Å, 135.22(4)º].X-ray crystal structures of [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2Suitable crystals of [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 was obtained from a acetonitrile/methanol solution by slow diffusion of diethyl ether. The ORTEP view of the complex is shown in Fig. 5. Crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters are given in Table 1 and selected bond distances and angles are given in Fig. 1.[NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 crystallizes in the monoclinic P-1 space group. The Ni(II) ion binds to two nitrogen of acetonitrile N(3) and N(4) and two oxygen atoms of methanol, O(3) and O(4) and also the azomethine nitrogen atoms N(1) and N(2) in a distorted octahedral geometry. The Ni-N bond lengths are nearly identical to each other (Ni(1)-N(1) 2.10(4) Å, Ni(1)-N(2) 2.09(3) Å) with a N(1)-Ni(1)-N(2) bond angle of 85.43(14)°. The bond length of Ni(1)-O(3) and Ni(1)-O(4) are 2.08(4) Å and 2.17(5) Å, respectively. The ether oxygen atoms in 16-membered macrocycle, O(1) and O(2), are not coordinated, lying at 4.86(3) Å and 5.08(3) Å, distances, respectively, from the Ni(II) ion [67]. The perchlorate anions do not interact with the metal ion.Antibacterial activitiesAntibacterial activities of the chemicals were studied against  four gram-positive and four gram-negative bacterial strains (Table 2). The all prepared chemicals inhibited the growth of bacterial strains producing a zone diameter of inhibition from 8.0 to 14.0 mm, depending on the susceptibility of the tested bacteria. The most effective ones are [Cu2L21](NO3)2 against Bacillus cereus, [Cu2L22](NO3)2 against Klebsiella oxytoca, and [Cu2L23](NO3)2 against Klebsiella oxytoca. Although the most studied chemicals exhibited antibacterial properties but their effects are less than a standard Chloramphenicol antibiotic.Since the comparison of the size of inhibition zones merely is not trustworthy, the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of the chemicals was also determined according to the method of NCCLS [55]. Results indicated that the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of the chemicals against the tested organisms varied between 16 against Bacillus cereus and Klebsiella oxytoca until 22 against Staphylococcus saprophyticus µg mL-1. The standard chloramphenicol had MIC values varying between 1 and 8 µg mL-1. The results indicated that standard antibiotic chloramphenicol had stranger activity than the chemicals against some bacterial strains. Antibacterial effect of the other chemicals is also notable.ConclusionIn summary, we report the successful synthesis of four macrocyclic Schiff base ligands by the [1+1] condensation of 1,2-diaminoethane or 1,3-diaminopropane, 2,2 dimethyl 1,3-diaminopropane or 1, 2-diaminopropane and 1,2-bis(2-formylphenoxymethyl)benzene. These ligands were characterized by various spectroscopic methods. After addition of the Ni(II) metal salt to the metanolic solution of L1 and L4, two macrocyclic complexes have been obtained but after addition of the copper(II) nitrate to the metanolic solution of ligands, three polymeric open-chain complexes have been obtained. The crystal structures of [Cu2L21'](NO3)2 can be best described as 1D zigzag chain coordination polymer and crystal structure of [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 show macrocyclic one. Results of this research showed that most prepared chemicals have relatively antibacterial effects against the studied bacterial strains, but the most effective ones are [Cu2L21'](NO3)2 against Bacillus cereus, [Cu2L22'](NO3)2 against Klebsiella oxytoca, and [Cu2L23'](NO3)2 against Klebsiella oxytoca.AcknowledgmentsWe are grateful to the Faculty of Chemistry of Bu-Ali Sina University, Ministry of Science, Research and Technology of Iran for financial support.References1.RezaeivalaMKeypourHCoord. elements.content: Four macrocyclic Schiff base ligands (L1, L2, L3, and L4) have been prepared. In the presence of Copper(II), original macrocycles were converted to the three new binuclear polymeric complexes [Cu2L21′](NO3)2, [Cu2L22′](NO3), and [Cu2L23′](NO3)2. But in the presence of Nickel(II), macrocyclic rings remained unchanged and Schiff base complexes of [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 and [NiL4](NO3)2 were synthesized. All ligands and their related complexes were characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy, in the case of ligands 1H, 13C NMR and EI-Mass and for [Cu2L2′](NO3)2 and [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 complexes X-ray crystal structure determination have been performed. Crystal structure showed 1D zigzag polymer for [Cu2L21′](NO3)2 and macrocyclic structure for [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 complexes. The ligands and related polymeric complexes were screened for their antibacterial activities against six bacterial strains and the complexes showed antibacterial effects.
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Four macrocyclic Schiff base ligands (L1, L2, L3, and L4) have been prepared. In the presence of Copper(II), original macrocycles were converted to the three new binuclear polymeric complexes [Cu2L21'](NO3)2, [Cu2L22'](NO3), and [Cu2L23'](NO3)2. But in the presence of Nickel(II), macrocyclic rings remained unchanged and Schiff base complexes of [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 and [NiL4](NO3)2 were synthesized. All ligands and their related complexes  were characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy, in the case of ligands 1H, 13C NMR and EI-Mass and for [Cu2L2'](NO3)2 and [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 complexes X-ray crystal structure determination have been performed. Crystal structure showed 1D zigzag polymer for [Cu2L21'](NO3)2 and macrocyclic structure for [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 complexes. The ligands and related polymeric complexes were screened for their antibacterial activities against six bacterial strains and the complexes showed antibacterial effects.

elements.content: The interest in exploring new metal ion complexes with macrocycles containing nitrogen and oxygen donor atoms has been increasing, because they became very attractive to be used in supramolecular and coordination chemistry [1]. Particularly important are systems that are related to bioactive molecules such as metalloporphyrins, corrins, and antibiotics [2]. X-ray structures of key complexes (largely containing metal ions of intermediate hardness) were determined and collectively indicated a varied structural chemistry across the complexes investigated. While, in a number of structures, the metal ion occupies the macrocyclic cavity and binds to all five ring donors [3, 4], in other cases non-coordination of either donors were observed [5–8] with the metal residing either endo or exo with respect to the macrocyclic cavity; or in some cases the presence of metal ion could change structure of ligands [9]. There is a continued interest in synthesizing macrocyclic complexes [10, 11] because of their applications in fundamental and applied sciences [12, 13] and importance in the area of coordination chemistry and for their biological properties, i.e., toxicity against bacterial growth [14], anticancerous [15], and other biochemical properties [16].
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The interest in exploring new metal ion complexes with macrocycles containing nitrogen and oxygen donor atoms has been increasing, because they became very attractive to be used in supramolecular and coordination chemistry [1]. Particularly important are systems that are related to bioactive molecules such as metalloporphyrins, corrins, and antibiotics [2]. X-ray structures of key complexes (largely containing metal ions of intermediate hardness) were determined and collectively indicated a varied structural chemistry across the complexes investigated. While, in a number of structures, the metal ion occupies the macrocyclic cavity and binds to all five ring donors [3, 4], in other cases non-coordination of either donors were observed [5-8] with the metal residing either endo or exo with respect to the macrocyclic cavity; or in some cases the presence of metal ion could change structure of ligands [9]. There is a continued interest in synthesizing macrocyclic complexes [10, 11] because of their applications in fundamental and applied sciences [12, 13] and importance in the area of coordination chemistry and for their biological properties, i.e., toxicity against bacterial growth [14], anticancerous [15], and other biochemical properties [16].

elements.content: Schiff base ligands are among the most versatile and useful ligands and their metal complexes have been widely used as catalysts for many organic reactions such as ring-opening polymerization and oxidation [17–20]. Some research groups have studied the structural and magnetic characterization of mono- and binuclear complexes of transition metal ions containing N2O2 tetradentate Schiff base ligands [21–33] specially copper(II) and nickle(II) complexes [34–40].

Some research groups have studied the structural and magnetic characterization of mono- and binuclear complexes of transition metal ions containing N2O2 tetradentate Schiff base ligands [21-33] specially copper(II) and nickle(II) complexes [34-40].

elements.content: Recently, we reported the biological activities of some new synthesized Schiff base complexes [41–45]. As an extension of this idea, we report in this work the synthesis, characterization, and antibacterial activities of four potentially tetradentate macrocyclic Schiff base ligands, L1, L2, L3, and L4 from [1+1] cyclocondensation of 1,2-bis(2-formylphenoxymethyl)benzene and 1,2-diaminoethane or 1,2-diaminopropane or 1,3-diaminopropane or 2,2 dimethyl 1,3-diaminopropane. After the addition of the copper(II) salts to the ligand solutions, surprisingly three polymeric binuclear open-chain complexes have been isolated while by the addition of Ni(II) metal salts to the same related solution of macrocyclic ligands ring opening does not occur and related macrocyclic complexes have been obtained (Scheme 1). The crystal structures of [Cu2L21′](NO3)2 and [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 are also reported.
elements.clean_text: Recently, we reported the biological activities of some new synthesized Schiff base complexes [41-45]. As an extension of this idea, we report in this work the synthesis, characterization, and antibacterial activities of four potentially tetradentate macrocyclic Schiff base ligands, L1, L2, L3, and L4 from [1+1] cyclocondensation of 1,2-bis(2-formylphenoxymethyl)benzene and 1,2-diaminoethane or 1,2-diaminopropane or 1,3-diaminopropane or 2,2 dimethyl 1,3-diaminopropane. After the addition of the copper(II) salts to the ligand solutions, surprisingly three polymeric binuclear open-chain complexes have been isolated while by the addition of Ni(II) metal salts to the same related solution of macrocyclic ligands ring opening does not occur and related macrocyclic complexes have been obtained (Scheme 1). The crystal structures of [Cu2L21'](NO3)2 and [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 are also reported.

elements.content: α, α-O-Dibromoxylene, 1,2-diaminoethane, 1,3-diaminopropane, 2,2-dimethyl-1,3- propanediamine and 1,2-diaminopropane, and metal salts were obtained from the Merck Company and were used without further purification.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Chemical and starting materials

α, α-O-Dibromoxylene, 1,2-diaminoethane, 1,3-diaminopropane, 2,2-dimethyl-1,3- propanediamine and 1,2-diaminopropane, and metal salts were obtained from the Merck Company and were used without further purification.

elements.content:
Caution α, α-o-Dibromoxylene is a very caustic matter. While we have not experienced any problems with the compound described. It should be treated and handled with caution.

General synthesis of the ligands (<bold>2</bold>)

1,2-Bis(2-formylphenoxymethyl)benzene was prepared according to the literature method [46]. 1,2-Diaminoethane, 1,3-diaminopropane, 2,2-dimethyl 1,2-diaminopropane, and 1,2-diaminopropane (0.3 mmol) in dry methanol (10 mL) were added dropwise to a boiling solution of 1,2-bis(2-formylphenoxymethyl)benzene (0.104 g, 0.3 mmol) in the same solvent (15 mL). After being refluxed for 12 h, the solution was concentrated in rotary evaporated to ca. 5 mL and the precipitate was filtered and washed by diethyl ether and acetonitrile and dried in vacuum.

General synthesis of the ligands (2)

1,2-Bis(2-formylphenoxymethyl)benzene was prepared according to the literature method [46]. 1,2-Diaminoethane, 1,3-diaminopropane, 2,2-dimethyl 1,2-diaminopropane, and 1,2-diaminopropane (0.3 mmol) in dry methanol (10 mL) were added dropwise to a boiling solution of 1,2-bis(2-formylphenoxymethyl)benzene (0.104 g, 0.3 mmol) in the same solvent (15 mL). After being refluxed for 12 h, the solution was concentrated in rotary evaporated to ca. 5 mL and the precipitate was filtered and washed by diethyl ether and acetonitrile and dried in vacuum.

General method of synthesis of Cu(II) complexes

Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (0.108 g, 0.3 mmol) was dissolved in dry methanol (10 mL) and slowly added to a stirred boiling solution (20 mml) of L1, L2, or L3 (0.3 mmol) in the same solvent with refluxing continuing for 6 h. The solution was reduced to ca. 5 ml and the precipitate was filtered and washed by diethyl ether and acetonitrile and dried in vacuum. Crystals suitable of [Cu2L21'](NO3)2 for X-ray diffraction studies were obtained by slow diffusion of Et2O vapor into the MeOH/MeCN solution of the above solid.

General method of Synthesis of Ni(II) complexes

Ni(II) metal salts (0.25 mmol) were dissolved in dry methanol (10 mL) and slowly added to a stirred boiling solution (20 mmol) of L1 or L4 (0.3 mmol) in the same solvent with refluxing continued for 6 h. The solution was reduced to ca. 5 ml and the precipitate was filtered and washed by diethyl ether and dried in vacuum. Crystals suitable of [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 for X-ray diffraction studies were obtained by slow diffusion of Et2O vapor into the MeOH/MeCN solution of the above solid.

elements.content: Single-crystal data for [Cu2L21′](NO3)2 and [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 were collected at room temperature with a Bruker APEX II CCD area-detector diffractometer using Mo Ka radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data collection, cell refinement, data reduction, and absorption correction were performed using multiscan methods with Bruker software [47–49]. The structures were solved by direct methods using SIR2004 [50]. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by the full-matrix least-squares method on F2 using SHELXL [51]. The hydrogen atoms of NH2 groups were found in difference Fourier map and refined isotropically. The other hydrogen (H) atoms were placed at the calculated positions and constrained to ride on their parent atoms. Details concerning collection and analysis are reported in Table 1.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystal structure determination

Single-crystal data for [Cu2L21'](NO3)2 and [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 were collected at room temperature with a Bruker APEX II CCD area-detector diffractometer using Mo Ka radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data collection, cell refinement, data reduction, and absorption correction were performed using multiscan methods with Bruker software [47-49]. The structures were solved by direct methods using SIR2004 [50]. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by the full-matrix least-squares method on F2 using SHELXL [51]. The hydrogen atoms of NH2 groups were found in difference Fourier map and refined isotropically. The other hydrogen (H) atoms were placed at the calculated positions and constrained to ride on their parent atoms. Details concerning collection and analysis are reported in Table 1.

The standard strains of the following microorganisms were used as test organisms: Salmonella typhi (Lio), Escherichia coli (PTCC 10009), Serratia marcescens (PTCC 1330), Klebsiella oxytoca (Lio), Bacillus cereus (ATCC 7064), and Staphylococcus saprophyticus (ATCC 6633). Some microorganisms were obtained from Persian Type Culture Collection, Tehran, Iran and others locally isolated (Lio). The organisms were sub-cultured in nutrient broth and nutrient agar (Oxiod Ltd.) for using in experiments, while diagnostic sensitivity test agar (DST) (Oxoid Ltd.) was used in antibiotic sensitivity testing.
elements.clean_text:
Materials and methods

Antibacterial study

Test organisms for antibacterial assay

The standard strains of the following microorganisms were used as test organisms: Salmonella typhi (Lio), Escherichia coli (PTCC 10009), Serratia marcescens (PTCC 1330), Klebsiella oxytoca (Lio), Bacillus cereus (ATCC 7064), and Staphylococcus saprophyticus (ATCC 6633). Some microorganisms were obtained from Persian Type Culture Collection, Tehran, Iran and others locally isolated (Lio). The organisms were sub-cultured in nutrient broth and nutrient agar (Oxiod Ltd.) for using in experiments, while diagnostic sensitivity test agar (DST) (Oxoid Ltd.) was used in antibiotic sensitivity testing.

elements.content: For bioassays, suspension of approximately 1.5 × 108 cells per mL in sterile normal saline was prepared as described by Forbes et al. [52]. The sensitivity testing was determined using agar-gel diffusion method [53, 54]. In each disks 20 µL of each chemical, containing 10 µg in DMSO, were loaded. The minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of chemicals was also determined using a two-fold dilutions method (NCCLS [55]). The isolated bacterial strains were first grown in nutrient broth for 18 h before use. The inoculum suspensions were standardized and then tested against the effect of the chemicals at an amount of 20 µL for each disk in DST medium. The plates were later incubated at 37 ± 0.5 °C for 24 h after which they were observed for zones of inhibition. The effects were compared with the standard antibiotic chloramphenicol at a concentration of 1 mg/mL [56]. The minimum inhibitory concentrations (MIC) of the chemicals were also determined by tube-dilution techniques in Mueller–Hinton broth (Merck) according to NCCLS [55]. The experiments were repeated at least three times for each organism and the data were presented as the mean ± SE of 3–5 samples.
elements.clean_text:
Sensitivity testing

For bioassays, suspension of approximately 1.5 × 108 cells per mL in sterile normal saline was prepared as described by Forbes et al. [52]. The sensitivity testing was determined using agar-gel diffusion method [53, 54]. In each disks 20 µL of each chemical, containing 10 µg in DMSO, were loaded. The minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of chemicals was also determined using a two-fold dilutions method (NCCLS [55]). The isolated bacterial strains were first grown in nutrient broth for 18 h before use. The inoculum suspensions were standardized and then tested against the effect of the chemicals at an amount of 20 µL for each disk in DST medium. The plates were later incubated at 37 ± 0.5 °C for 24 h after which they were observed for zones of inhibition. The effects were compared with the standard antibiotic chloramphenicol at a concentration of 1 mg/mL [56]. The minimum inhibitory concentrations (MIC) of the chemicals were also determined by tube-dilution techniques in Mueller-Hinton broth (Merck) according to NCCLS [55]. The experiments were repeated at least three times for each organism and the data were presented as the mean ± SE of 3-5 samples.

elements.content: The Schiff base macrocyclic ligands, L1, L2, L3, and L4 were prepared from [1+1] condensation of 1,2-diaminoethane, 1,3-diaminopropane, 2,2-dimethyl 1,3-diamino propane, 1,2-diaminopropane, and 1,2-bis(2-formylphenoxymethyl)benzene. These ligands were characterized by elemental analyses, EI-Mass, IR spectroscopy, 1H NMR (in all case), and 13C NMR (in case of L1, L2, and L4). These solid compounds are air stable and elemental analyses are consistent with the formulations given in Sect. 2.
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

The Schiff base macrocyclic ligands, L1, L2, L3, and L4 were prepared from [1+1] condensation of 1,2-diaminoethane, 1,3-diaminopropane, 2,2-dimethyl 1,3-diamino propane, 1,2-diaminopropane, and 1,2-bis(2-formylphenoxymethyl)benzene. These ligands were characterized by elemental analyses, EI-Mass, IR spectroscopy, 1H NMR (in all case), and 13C NMR (in case of L1, L2, and L4). These solid compounds are air stable and elemental analyses are consistent with the formulations given in Sect. 2.

elements.content: In addition of the Cu(II) and Ni(II) metal salts to the metanolic solution of these different ligands, macrocyclic complexes (in the case of Ni(II) metal salt) and polymeric open-chain complexes (in the case of Cu(II) metal salt) have been obtained. In polymeric open-chain complexes, copper(II) nitrate plays a vital role in converting ligand structures to the polymeric open-chain complexes instead of macrocyclic ones. These complexes were characterized by elemental analyses and IR spectroscopy in all cases and X-ray crystallography in the case of [Cu2L21′](NO3)2 and [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 confirm the above suggestion. In previous work, in similar structures, we have reported that the closure of macrocyclic ring in the presence of Co(II) and Zn(II) metal ions did not occur but when Ni(II) or Cu(II) metal ions were used then only macrocyclic complexes were the final product [9]. In this work, because of the preferential structural requirement caused by exerting extra force due to steric hindrance imposed by the electronic nature of the copper(II) ion, polymeric open-chain complexes were obtained instead of macrocyclic ones.
elements.clean_text: In addition of the Cu(II) and Ni(II) metal salts to the metanolic solution of these different ligands, macrocyclic complexes (in the case of Ni(II) metal salt) and polymeric open-chain complexes (in the case of Cu(II) metal salt) have been obtained. In polymeric open-chain complexes, copper(II) nitrate plays a vital role in converting ligand structures to the polymeric open-chain complexes instead of macrocyclic ones. These complexes were characterized by elemental analyses and IR spectroscopy in all cases and X-ray crystallography in the case of [Cu2L21'](NO3)2 and [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 confirm the above suggestion. In previous work, in similar structures, we have reported that the closure of macrocyclic ring in the presence of Co(II) and Zn(II) metal ions did not occur but when Ni(II) or Cu(II) metal ions were used then only macrocyclic complexes were the final product [9]. In this work, because of the preferential structural requirement caused by exerting extra force due to steric hindrance imposed by the electronic nature of the copper(II) ion, polymeric open-chain complexes were obtained instead of macrocyclic ones.

elements.content: In all three similar IR spectra of prepared Cu(II) complexes, a sharp peak exhibit at the range 1623–1642 cm−1 have been referred to C=N vibration and nitrate groups have shown a peak at 1384 cm−1 and absorptions attributable to NH2 groups were found at approximately 3100–3300 cm−1. Elemental analyses of polymeric complexes are consistent with the formulations given in Sect. 2.

Crystal structures

Crystal structure of [Cu2L21'](NO3)2

The crystal structure of [Cu2L21'](NO3)2 has been determined by X-ray diffraction. The molecular structures with the atomic numbering scheme and selected bond lengths and bond angles are given in Fig. 2.

[Cu2L21](NO3)2 crystallizes in the monoclinic P2(1)/n space group. This is a binuclear complex. The first copper ion is coordinated to two oxygen atoms and two nitrogen atoms of ligand and one oxygen atom of nitrate group, and has distorted square pyramidal geometry. The second copper ion is coordinated also to another oxygen atom of nitrate ion as well and has distorted octahedral geometry. There is a moderate intramolecular hydrogen bond between the oxygen atom of nitrate group and hydrogen of NH2 group (N4-H4A…O6 (2.152(3) Å) (Fig. 3).

elements.content: Atoms O1 and O2 of this compound play as a bridge leading to a binuclear complex. O2-Cu2-N3 angle have minimum deviation (0.68°) and O2-Cu2-O1 have maximum deviation (14.62o) from normal range (90o) of a regular square. The four Cu–N bond lengths lay in the range 1.951–1.977 Å, affording an average Cu–N bond distance of 1.963 Å. The distances between the Cu atoms and oxygen atoms are between 1.921 and 2.012 Å (minimum for Cu1-O1 and maximum for Cu2-O1). The Cu–N and Cu–O bond length are all within a normal distance for a Cu–O and Cu–N bond length [57–66]. The Cu–Cu distance in the dimeric entity is 2.9538(4) Å. A further distinguishing feature in [Cu2L21′](NO3)2 is that the two coordinated nitrate groups are on the same side of the Cu2O2 ring in the dimer.

elements.content: In this structure, we have two different nitrate groups. One of them is as terminal group and another acts as bridge group. The two oxygen atoms of bridged nitrate group are linked to two different copper atoms that create 1D zigzag chain coordination polymer (Fig. 4). The two Cu–O bond lengths of bridged nitrate group are quite diverse [Cu(1)-O(4) = 2.450(2), Cu(2)-O(3) = 2.567 (3)].

elements.content: [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 crystallizes in the monoclinic P-1 space group. The Ni(II) ion binds to two nitrogen of acetonitrile N(3) and N(4) and two oxygen atoms of methanol, O(3) and O(4) and also the azomethine nitrogen atoms N(1) and N(2) in a distorted octahedral geometry. The Ni–N bond lengths are nearly identical to each other (Ni(1)-N(1) 2.10(4) Å, Ni(1)-N(2) 2.09(3) Å) with a N(1)-Ni(1)–N(2) bond angle of 85.43(14)°. The bond length of Ni(1)-O(3) and Ni(1)-O(4) are 2.08(4) Å and 2.17(5) Å, respectively. The ether oxygen atoms in 16-membered macrocycle, O(1) and O(2), are not coordinated, lying at 4.86(3) Å and 5.08(3) Å, distances, respectively, from the Ni(II) ion [67]. The perchlorate anions do not interact with the metal ion.

Since the comparison of the size of inhibition zones merely is not trustworthy, the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of the chemicals was also determined according to the method of NCCLS [55]. Results indicated that the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of the chemicals against the tested organisms varied between 16 against Bacillus cereus and Klebsiella oxytoca until 22 against Staphylococcus saprophyticus µg mL−1. The standard chloramphenicol had MIC values varying between 1 and 8 µg mL−1. The results indicated that standard antibiotic chloramphenicol had stranger activity than the chemicals against some bacterial strains. Antibacterial effect of the other chemicals is also notable.

elements.content: In summary, we report the successful synthesis of four macrocyclic Schiff base ligands by the [1+1] condensation of 1,2-diaminoethane or 1,3-diaminopropane, 2,2 dimethyl 1,3-diaminopropane or 1, 2-diaminopropane and 1,2-bis(2-formylphenoxymethyl)benzene. These ligands were characterized by various spectroscopic methods. After addition of the Ni(II) metal salt to the metanolic solution of L1 and L4, two macrocyclic complexes have been obtained but after addition of the copper(II) nitrate to the metanolic solution of ligands, three polymeric open-chain complexes have been obtained. The crystal structures of [Cu2L21′](NO3)2 can be best described as 1D zigzag chain coordination polymer and crystal structure of [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 show macrocyclic one. Results of this research showed that most prepared chemicals have relatively antibacterial effects against the studied bacterial strains, but the most effective ones are [Cu2L21′](NO3)2 against Bacillus cereus, [Cu2L22′](NO3)2 against Klebsiella oxytoca, and [Cu2L23′](NO3)2 against Klebsiella oxytoca.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we report the successful synthesis of four macrocyclic Schiff base ligands by the [1+1] condensation of 1,2-diaminoethane or 1,3-diaminopropane, 2,2 dimethyl 1,3-diaminopropane or 1, 2-diaminopropane and 1,2-bis(2-formylphenoxymethyl)benzene. These ligands were characterized by various spectroscopic methods. After addition of the Ni(II) metal salt to the metanolic solution of L1 and L4, two macrocyclic complexes have been obtained but after addition of the copper(II) nitrate to the metanolic solution of ligands, three polymeric open-chain complexes have been obtained. The crystal structures of [Cu2L21'](NO3)2 can be best described as 1D zigzag chain coordination polymer and crystal structure of [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 show macrocyclic one. Results of this research showed that most prepared chemicals have relatively antibacterial effects against the studied bacterial strains, but the most effective ones are [Cu2L21'](NO3)2 against Bacillus cereus, [Cu2L22'](NO3)2 against Klebsiella oxytoca, and [Cu2L23'](NO3)2 against Klebsiella oxytoca.

General method of Synthesis of Ni(II) complexes

Ni(II) metal salts (0.25 mmol) were dissolved in dry methanol (10 mL) and slowly added to a stirred boiling solution (20 mmol) of L1 or L4 (0.3 mmol) in the same solvent with refluxing continued for 6 h. The solution was reduced to ca. 5 ml and the precipitate was filtered and washed by diethyl ether and dried in vacuum. Crystals suitable of [NiL1(CH3CN)2(CH3OH)2](ClO4)2 for X-ray diffraction studies were obtained by slow diffusion of Et2O vapor into the MeOH/MeCN solution of the above solid.

Yield: 49 %. Anal. Calc. for: C30 H40 Cl2 N4 Ni O12: C, 32.90; H, 4.5; N, 6.0. Found: C, 32.89; H, 4.32; N, 5.78 %. IR (KBr, cm−1): 1651υ (C=), 1100 υ(ClO4−).

[NiL<sup>4</sup>] (NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>

Yield: 35 % (0.05 g). Anal. Calc. for C25H24N4O8Ni: C, 52.90; H, 4.30; N, 9.90. Found: C, 52.50; H, 4.60; N, 9.70 %. IR (KBr, cm−1): 1618 υ (C=N), 1384, υ(NO3−).

Physical measurements

IR spectra were measured on a Perkin Elmer FT-IRGX spectrophotometer. Mass spectra were recorded using VARIAN 3400 GC-Mass spectrometer. NMR spectra were measured on Bruker DPX 400 spectrometers. Elemental analyses were performed in a Carlo-Erba EA microanalyser.

Antibacterial activities

Antibacterial activities of the chemicals were studied against four gram-positive and four gram-negative bacterial strains (Table 2). The all prepared chemicals inhibited the growth of bacterial strains producing a zone diameter of inhibition from 8.0 to 14.0 mm, depending on the susceptibility of the tested bacteria. The most effective ones are [Cu2L21](NO3)2 against Bacillus cereus, [Cu2L22](NO3)2 against Klebsiella oxytoca, and [Cu2L23](NO3)2 against Klebsiella oxytoca. Although the most studied chemicals exhibited antibacterial properties but their effects are less than a standard Chloramphenicol antibiotic.

Since the comparison of the size of inhibition zones merely is not trustworthy, the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of the chemicals was also determined according to the method of NCCLS [55]. Results indicated that the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of the chemicals against the tested organisms varied between 16 against Bacillus cereus and Klebsiella oxytoca until 22 against Staphylococcus saprophyticus µg mL−1. The standard chloramphenicol had MIC values varying between 1 and 8 µg mL−1. The results indicated that standard antibiotic chloramphenicol had stranger activity than the chemicals against some bacterial strains. Antibacterial effect of the other chemicals is also notable.
